body.p: The head and neck region receives sensory innervation through the divisions of the trigeminal nerve.1 Stimulation of the trigeminal receptors in the nasal cavity during diving can cause reflex bradycardia and hypotension with peripheral vasoconstriction (ie, the diving reflex). This oxygen-conserving effect for the vital organs—heart and brain—thus delays the onset of serious hypoxic damage. The diving reflex is now considered one of the various presentations of a much broader reflex mechanism: the trigeminocardiac reflex (TCR). This reflex is described as the sudden occurrence of dysrhythmia, hypotension, apnea, or gastric hypermotility upon stimulation of any of the sensory branches of the trigeminal nerve.1

Bradycardia due to the TCR can occur during several maxillofacial, skull base, and ophthalmic procedures. Here we report a case of reversible bradycardia that occurred during a total conservative parotidectomy. This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board (Ethics Committee), Christian Medical College, Vellore, India.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 54-year-old woman presented with complaints of a progressively increasing swelling in the upper left cervical region for 5 months. On examination, a 4 × 4-cm firm nodular swelling was noted in the region of the left parotid gland with no palpable cervical lymph nodes. She underwent superficial parotidectomy that revealed a high-grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma. In accordance with the multidisciplinary tumor board recommendation, she subsequently underwent a completion parotidectomy with electrophysiological facial nerve monitoring and left modified radical neck dissection under general anesthesia, using propofol and isoflurane. The patient’s baseline heart rate was 86 beats per minute and blood pressure was 130/80 mm Hg. At parotidectomy, during the dissection of the left internal maxillary artery, she developed repeated episodes of bradycardia (heart rate reducing to 40 beats per minute), which reversed within moments of withdrawal of the mechanical stimulus. After several attempts and patient dissection around the artery, the left internal maxillary artery was eventually secured and the operation was completed. The patient made an uneventful recovery.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The TCR has been described during many neurosurgical, ophthalmological, and maxillofacial procedures, including strabismus surgeries, Le-Fort I fracture repair, elevation of zygomatic arch fractures, temporomandibular joint arthroscopies, and transsphenoidal pituitary surgeries.2,3 This reflex is mediated via the sensory nerve endings of the trigeminal nerve that send sensory signals via the Gasserian ganglion to the trigeminal nucleus (pons), the afferent limb of the reflex arc. This pathway continues from the ventral trigeminal nucleus through the internuncial fibers in the reticular formation to synapse on parasympathetic cardiac vagal neurons (CVNs) in the nucleus ambiguus. Parasympathetic fibers from the nucleus ambiguus innervate the heart and constitute the efferent limb of the reflex arc (Figure 1).4

caption.p: Schematic diagram representing the trigeminocardiac reflex pathway involving the trigeminal afferent fibers up to the level of pons, after which the parasympathetic impulses reach the heart via the cardiac vagal neurons.

sec.p: Factors such as young age, light plane of anesthesia, beta-blocker drugs, and the degree of stimulus are thought to increase the risk of the TCR.4 Ketamine inhibits the reflex by inhibiting glutamatergic neurotransmission at the trigeminal nucleus as well as the CVNs. Local anesthetic infiltration may inhibit the TCR via afferent receptor blockade.5

The patient in the present case developed repeated episodes of significant bradycardia (40-50 beats/min) on mechanical stimulation of the internal maxillary artery. Presumably, a lighter plane of anesthesia, which was needed for electrophysiological facial nerve monitoring, might have been the reason. Either a cardiac or neuronal absolute refractory period caused fatigability of this reflex, which eventually aided in the ligation of the internal maxillary artery. The key factor, then, is a prompt recognition of bradycardia and immediate withdrawal of the stimulus to avoid persistent bradycardia or even complete asystole. Removal of the triggering factor generally causes cessation of the reflex, but occasionally anticholinergics may be required.

To the best of our knowledge, this is the first instance of the TCR during a parotid surgery in the reported English literature. The purpose of this report is to inform the scientific community about the occurrence of the TCR and its attendant problems during parotid operations.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A possibility of the TCR should be borne in mind by both the surgeon and the anesthesiologist during total parotidectomies when bradycardia may occur during manipulation of the vessels in the region of innervation of the trigeminal nerves. Appropriate selection of anesthetic agents for high-risk patients, anticipation, patient dissection, vigilance, and early intervention during the operation are the key factors for a successful surgery in this region.
